elements.content: A Raman spectroscopic evaluation of numerous crystalline solvates with lithium bis­(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)­imide (LiTFSI or LiN­(SO2CF3)2) has been conducted over a wide temperature range. Four new crystalline solvate structures(PHEN)3:LiTFSI, (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI, (G3)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI with phenanthroline, 2,9-dimethyl­[1,10]­phenanthroline, triglyme, and 2,6-dimethylpyridine, respectivelyhave been determined to aid in this study. The spectroscopic data have been correlated with varying modes of TFSI–···Li+ cation coordination within the solvate structures to create an electrolyte characterization tool to facilitate the Raman band deconvolution assignments for the determination of ionic association interactions within electrolytes containing LiTFSI. It is found, however, that significant difficulties may be encountered when identifying the distributions of specific forms of TFSI– anion coordination present in liquid electrolyte mixtures due to the wide range of TFSI–···Li+ cation interactions possible and the overlap of the corresponding spectroscopic data signatures.
elements.clean_text: A Raman spectroscopic evaluation of numerous crystalline solvates with lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI or LiN(SO2CF3)2) has been conducted over a wide temperature range. Four new crystalline solvate structures(PHEN)3:LiTFSI, (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI, (G3)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI with phenanthroline, 2,9-dimethyl[1,10]phenanthroline, triglyme, and 2,6-dimethylpyridine, respectivelyhave been determined to aid in this study. The spectroscopic data have been correlated with varying modes of TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination within the solvate structures to create an electrolyte characterization tool to facilitate the Raman band deconvolution assignments for the determination of ionic association interactions within electrolytes containing LiTFSI. It is found, however, that significant difficulties may be encountered when identifying the distributions of specific forms of TFSI- anion coordination present in liquid electrolyte mixtures due to the wide range of TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation interactions possible and the overlap of the corresponding spectroscopic data signatures.

elements.content: Understanding the molecular-level interactions in electrolyte mixtures is crucial because such interactions determine the electrolyte properties and correspondingly influence the performance, safety, and longevity of batteries. The most widely utilized methods for scrutinizing such interactions are Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and Raman spectroscopy. Upon coordination with Li+ cations, the vibrational bands of the anions are shifted due to changes in the anion’s electron density and structure. The variation in these shifts is dependent upon the manner in which one or more Li+ cations are coordinated. Detailed information about the molecular-level interactions is therefore obtainable if one can correlate the experimental data to specific forms of coordination. Without such a key, however, the evaluation of experimental spectroscopic data is fraught with pitfalls as a misinterpretation of the data leads to highly erroneous conclusions about ionic association interactions within electrolytes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Understanding the molecular-level interactions in electrolyte mixtures is crucial because such interactions determine the electrolyte properties and correspondingly influence the performance, safety, and longevity of batteries. The most widely utilized methods for scrutinizing such interactions are Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) and Raman spectroscopy. Upon coordination with Li+ cations, the vibrational bands of the anions are shifted due to changes in the anion's electron density and structure. The variation in these shifts is dependent upon the manner in which one or more Li+ cations are coordinated. Detailed information about the molecular-level interactions is therefore obtainable if one can correlate the experimental data to specific forms of coordination. Without such a key, however, the evaluation of experimental spectroscopic data is fraught with pitfalls as a misinterpretation of the data leads to highly erroneous conclusions about ionic association interactions within electrolytes.

elements.content: To address this problem, previous studies have been reported for LiClO4, LiBF4, and LiDFOB (i.e., lithium difluoro­(oxalato)­borate) which examine the anion band variation of crystalline solvates with known anion···Li+ cation coordination to identify solvent-separated ion pair (SSIP), contact ion pair (CIP), and aggregate (AGG) coordination in which the anions are coordinated to zero, one, or more than one Li+ cations, respectively. Such studies provide electrolyte characterization tools which may be broadly utilized for a given lithium salt. The present study continues this evaluation for the widely studied salt lithium bis­(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)­imide (i.e., LiTFSI or LiN­(SO2CF3)2):
elements.clean_text: To address this problem, previous studies have been reported for LiClO4, LiBF4, and LiDFOB (i.e., lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate) which examine the anion band variation of crystalline solvates with known anion⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination to identify solvent-separated ion pair (SSIP), contact ion pair (CIP), and aggregate (AGG) coordination in which the anions are coordinated to zero, one, or more than one Li+ cations, respectively. Such studies provide electrolyte characterization tools which may be broadly utilized for a given lithium salt. The present study continues this evaluation for the widely studied salt lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (i.e., LiTFSI or LiN(SO2CF3)2):

elements.content: The TFSI– anion has extensive charge delocalization (i.e., multiple resonance structures). The anion is also flexible with two low-energy conformations: a cisoid form (C 1) with the CF3 groups on the same side of the S–N–S plane and a transoid form (C 2) with the CF3 groups on opposite side of the plane. In solution, an equilibrium exists between these conformations with the C 2 conformation expected to be lower in energy from gas-phase calculations. In crystalline phases, however, the TFSI– anion often has only one conformationeither C 1 or C 2. In addition, the TFSI– anion is able to readily adopt bidentate coordination to a single Li+ cation with two oxygen atoms. A more descriptive classification than for simpler anionssuch as BF4 – and ClO4 – which are not flexible and thus have only a single conformation resulting in fewer modes of Li+ cation coordinationis therefore necessary for Li+ cation coordination by the TFSI– anion (Chart ): SSIP uncoordinated anion CIP-I 1 anion O coordinated to 1 Li+ CIP-II 2 anion O coordinated to 1 Li+ AGG-Ia 2 anion O coordinated to 2 Li+ AGG-Ib 3 anion O coordinated to 2 Li+ AGG-IIa 3 anion O coordinated to 3 Li+ AGG-IIb 4 anion O coordinated to 3 Li+ AGG-III 4 anion O coordinated to 4+ Li+
elements.clean_text: The TFSI- anion has extensive charge delocalization (i.e., multiple resonance structures). The anion is also flexible with two low-energy conformations: a cisoid form (C 1) with the CF3 groups on the same side of the S-N-S plane and a transoid form (C 2) with the CF3 groups on opposite side of the plane. In solution, an equilibrium exists between these conformations with the C 2 conformation expected to be lower in energy from gas-phase calculations. In crystalline phases, however, the TFSI- anion often has only one conformationeither C 1 or C 2. In addition, the TFSI- anion is able to readily adopt bidentate coordination to a single Li+ cation with two oxygen atoms. A more descriptive classification than for simpler anionssuch as BF4 - and ClO4 - which are not flexible and thus have only a single conformation resulting in fewer modes of Li+ cation coordinationis therefore necessary for Li+ cation coordination by the TFSI- anion (Chart ):   SSIP uncoordinated anion   CIP-I 1 anion O coordinated to 1 Li+    CIP-II 2 anion O coordinated to 1 Li+    AGG-Ia 2 anion O coordinated to 2 Li+    AGG-Ib 3 anion O coordinated to 2 Li+    AGG-IIa 3 anion O coordinated to 3 Li+    AGG-IIb 4 anion O coordinated to 3 Li+    AGG-III 4 anion O coordinated to 4+ Li+

elements.content:
Example of TFSI<sup>–</sup>···Li<sup>+</sup> Cation Coordination (from Crystal Structures): (a) SSIP-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>1</sub>, (b) SSIP-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>2</sub>, (c) CIP-I-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>2</sub>, (d) CIP-II-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>1</sub>, (e) AGG-Ia-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>2</sub>, (f) AGG-Ib-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>2</sub>, (g) AGG-IIb-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>1</sub>, (h) AGG-IIb-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>2</sub>, and (i) AGG-III-<italic toggle="yes">C</italic> <sub>2</sub> <xref rid="c1fn1"></xref>

Other forms of coordination may also occur. Li+ cations are colored black.
elements.clean_text: 1  Example of TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ Cation Coordination (from Crystal Structures): (a) SSIP-C 1, (b) SSIP-C 2, (c) CIP-I-C 2, (d) CIP-II-C 1, (e) AGG-Ia-C 2, (f) AGG-Ib-C 2, (g) AGG-IIb-C 1, (h) AGG-IIb-C 2, and (i) AGG-III-C 2       a Other forms of coordination may also occur. Li+ cations are colored black.

elements.content:
Other forms of coordination may also occur. Li+ cations are colored black.

As part of the present evaluation, different crystalline solvates were prepared and analyzed based upon this classification. The results reported here make it clear that a rigorous deconvolution of specific forms of TFSI–···Li+ cation coordination for electrolyte liquid mixtures is a difficult challenge. This is due to both the diversity present in the manner in which the anions may be coordinated and the overlap of Raman bands for these different forms of coordination. Significant information may still be learned about anion coordination in solution, however, when spectroscopic information is combined with other methods of electrolyte characterization. As an example of its utility, the information obtained from the present work has been directly used to evaluate the solution structural interactions within acetonitrile (AN) n -LiTFSI liquid electrolytes.
elements.clean_text:
a Other forms of coordination may also occur. Li+ cations are colored black.  

As part of the present evaluation, different crystalline solvates were prepared and analyzed based upon this classification. The results reported here make it clear that a rigorous deconvolution of specific forms of TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination for electrolyte liquid mixtures is a difficult challenge. This is due to both the diversity present in the manner in which the anions may be coordinated and the overlap of Raman bands for these different forms of coordination. Significant information may still be learned about anion coordination in solution, however, when spectroscopic information is combined with other methods of electrolyte characterization. As an example of its utility, the information obtained from the present work has been directly used to evaluate the solution structural interactions within acetonitrile (AN) n -LiTFSI liquid electrolytes.

elements.content: LiTFSI (battery grade) was purchased from 3M. The salt was dried at 120 °C under high vacuum overnight. The solvents (Chart ) ethylene glycol dimethyl ether, 1,2-dimethoxyethane or monoglyme (G1, anhydrous, 99.5%), diethylene glycol dimethyl ether, 2-methoxyethyl ether or diglyme (G2, anhydrous, 99.5%), triethylene glycol dimethyl ether or triglyme (G3, 99%), N,N,N′,N″,N″-pentamethyldiethylenetriamine (PMDETA, 99%), N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA, purified by re-distillation, ≥99.5%), ethylene carbonate (EC, 99%), 1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclododecane or 12-crown-4 (12C4, 98%), phenanthroline (PHEN, ≥99%), neocuproine or 2,9-dimethyl­[1,10]­phenanthroline (2,9-DMPHEN, ≥99.0%), 2,6-lutidine or 2,6-dimethylpyridine (2,6-DMPy, ≥99.0%), and acetonitrile (AN, anhydrous, 99.9%) were purchased from either Fisher Scientific or Sigma-Aldrich. These solvents were dried over 3 Å molecular sieves (for the liquids), and the water content of the solvents was verified prior to their use to be negligible (<30 ppm) using a Mettler Toledo DL39 Karl Fischer coulometer. The solids were used as-received. The materials were stored and handled in a Vacuum Atmospheres inert atmosphere (N2) glovebox (<5 ppm of H2O).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods

Materials

LiTFSI (battery grade) was purchased from 3M. The salt was dried at 120 °C under high vacuum overnight. The solvents (Chart ) ethylene glycol dimethyl ether, 1,2-dimethoxyethane or monoglyme (G1, anhydrous, 99.5%), diethylene glycol dimethyl ether, 2-methoxyethyl ether or diglyme (G2, anhydrous, 99.5%), triethylene glycol dimethyl ether or triglyme (G3, 99%), N,N,N',N",N"-pentamethyldiethylenetriamine (PMDETA, 99%), N,N,N',N'-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA, purified by re-distillation, ≥99.5%), ethylene carbonate (EC, 99%), 1,4,7,10-tetraoxacyclododecane or 12-crown-4 (12C4, 98%), phenanthroline (PHEN, ≥99%), neocuproine or 2,9-dimethyl[1,10]phenanthroline (2,9-DMPHEN, ≥99.0%), 2,6-lutidine or 2,6-dimethylpyridine (2,6-DMPy, ≥99.0%), and acetonitrile (AN, anhydrous, 99.9%) were purchased from either Fisher Scientific or Sigma-Aldrich. These solvents were dried over 3 Å molecular sieves (for the liquids), and the water content of the solvents was verified prior to their use to be negligible (<30 ppm) using a Mettler Toledo DL39 Karl Fischer coulometer. The solids were used as-received. The materials were stored and handled in a Vacuum Atmospheres inert atmosphere (N2) glovebox (<5 ppm of H2O).

elements.clean_text: 2  Structures and Acronyms of the Solvents Studied

elements.content: Mixtures were prepared in the glovebox by combining appropriate amounts of LiTFSI and the desired solvents in hermetically sealed glass vials. The mixtures were heated and stirred on a hot plate until the salt fully dissolved. To obtain single crystals, mixtures more dilute than the desired solvate stoichiometry were typically prepared. Single crystals grew from the mixtures upon standing either at room temperature, at 4 °C (in a refrigerator) or at −23 °C (in a freezer) (). The single crystals were used both for the determination of the solvate structures via single-crystal X-ray diffraction and for the Raman analysis. For the latter, the crystals were ground in the glovebox into a fine powder using a mortar and pestle (if the T m of the solvate is greater than room temperature) to avoid crystal orientation effects. For the solvates which have a T m at or below room temperature, mixtures were instead prepared with the stoichiometric amount of solvent and salt for the solvates and the samples were crystallized directly in a Linkam heating/cooling stage just prior to the Raman measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Sample Preparation

Mixtures were prepared in the glovebox by combining appropriate amounts of LiTFSI and the desired solvents in hermetically sealed glass vials. The mixtures were heated and stirred on a hot plate until the salt fully dissolved. To obtain single crystals, mixtures more dilute than the desired solvate stoichiometry were typically prepared. Single crystals grew from the mixtures upon standing either at room temperature, at 4 °C (in a refrigerator) or at -23 °C (in a freezer) (). The single crystals were used both for the determination of the solvate structures via single-crystal X-ray diffraction and for the Raman analysis. For the latter, the crystals were ground in the glovebox into a fine powder using a mortar and pestle (if the T m of the solvate is greater than room temperature) to avoid crystal orientation effects. For the solvates which have a T m at or below room temperature, mixtures were instead prepared with the stoichiometric amount of solvent and salt for the solvates and the samples were crystallized directly in a Linkam heating/cooling stage just prior to the Raman measurements.

elements.content: The methods for the solvate single-crystal preparation and details of the X-ray diffraction methods used for the structural analyses are provided in the . Structures were drawn using either Mercury 3.0 or Ortep-3. Crystallographic information data files (CIFs) for the solvates are available in the and free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif: CCDC 928322 (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, 937691 (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI, 934182 (G3)1:LiTFSI, and 928323 (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI. Mercury freeware software to view the content of these files is also available: www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/free_services/mercury/downloads/.
elements.clean_text:
Solvate Crystal Structure Determination

The methods for the solvate single-crystal preparation and details of the X-ray diffraction methods used for the structural analyses are provided in the . Structures were drawn using either Mercury 3.0 or Ortep-3. Crystallographic information data files (CIFs) for the solvates are available in the  and free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif: CCDC 928322 (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, 937691 (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI, 934182 (G3)1:LiTFSI, and 928323 (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI. Mercury freeware software to view the content of these files is also available: www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/free_services/mercury/downloads/.

elements.content: Raman vibrational spectra were collected with a Horiba-JobinYvon LabRAM HR VIS high-resolution confocal Raman microscope, using a 632 nm–1 He–Ne laser as the exciting source, a 3600 grooves/mm grating, and a Linkam heating/cooling stage for temperature control with a long-distance 50× objective. The spectral resolution is ≤1 cm–1. The instrument was calibrated with a monocrystalline Si wafer at 520.7 cm–1. The samples were contained in a depression cut into an aluminum plate which was hermetically sealed in the Linkam stage in the glovebox before transferring the stage to the spectrometer. Spectra were typically collected using a 10–30 s exposure time with 10 accumulations to ensure that high-resolution spectra were obtained. The samples were cooled/heated at a 5 °C min–1 rate, and the spectra were collected from −100 to 60 °C at intervals of 20 °C. Raman spectra were processed using LabSpec software.
elements.clean_text:
Raman Measurements

Raman vibrational spectra were collected with a Horiba-JobinYvon LabRAM HR VIS high-resolution confocal Raman microscope, using a 632 nm-1 He-Ne laser as the exciting source, a 3600 grooves/mm grating, and a Linkam heating/cooling stage for temperature control with a long-distance 50× objective. The spectral resolution is ≤1 cm-1. The instrument was calibrated with a monocrystalline Si wafer at 520.7 cm-1. The samples were contained in a depression cut into an aluminum plate which was hermetically sealed in the Linkam stage in the glovebox before transferring the stage to the spectrometer. Spectra were typically collected using a 10-30 s exposure time with 10 accumulations to ensure that high-resolution spectra were obtained. The samples were cooled/heated at a 5 °C min-1 rate, and the spectra were collected from -100 to 60 °C at intervals of 20 °C. Raman spectra were processed using LabSpec software.

elements.content: Several LiTFSI solvate structures have been previously reported: SSIP (G2)2:LiTFSI and (12C4)2:LiTFSI; CIP-II (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI; AGG-I (G1)1:LiTFSI, (EC)3:LiTFSI, and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI; and AGG-II (AN)1:LiTFSI, and (EC)1:LiTFSI (Figure ). The crystal structure of the pure LiTFSI salt has also previously been reported (Figure ). New crystal structures determined as part of the present study include the following: SSIP (PHEN)3:LiTFSI and (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI; CIP-II (G3)1:LiTFSI; AGG-II (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvate Structures and Li+ Cation Coordination

Several LiTFSI solvate structures have been previously reported: SSIP (G2)2:LiTFSI and (12C4)2:LiTFSI; CIP-II (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI; AGG-I (G1)1:LiTFSI, (EC)3:LiTFSI, and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI; and AGG-II (AN)1:LiTFSI, and (EC)1:LiTFSI (Figure ). The crystal structure of the pure LiTFSI salt has also previously been reported (Figure ). New crystal structures determined as part of the present study include the following: SSIP (PHEN)3:LiTFSI and (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI; CIP-II (G3)1:LiTFSI; AGG-II (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI (Figure ).

elements.content: TFSI–···Li+ cation coordination in solvates which have previously been reported: (a) SSIP-C 2 (G2)2:LiTFSI, (b) CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI, (c) AGG-Ib-C 2 (G1)1:LiTFSI, (d) AGG-Ia-C 2 (EC)3:LiTFSI, (e) AGG-Ib-C 2 (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI, (f) AGG-IIb-C 2 (EC)1:LiTFSI, (g) AGG-IIb-C 1 (AN)1:LiTFSI, and (h) AGG-III-C 2 pure LiTFSI. ,
elements.clean_text: 1  TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination in solvates which have previously been reported: (a) SSIP-C 2 (G2)2:LiTFSI, (b) CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI, (c) AGG-Ib-C 2 (G1)1:LiTFSI, (d) AGG-Ia-C 2 (EC)3:LiTFSI, (e) AGG-Ib-C 2 (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI, (f) AGG-IIb-C 2 (EC)1:LiTFSI, (g) AGG-IIb-C 1 (AN)1:LiTFSI, and (h) AGG-III-C 2 pure LiTFSI. ,

elements.content: TFSI–···Li+ cation coordination in the newly reported LiTFSI solvates: (a) SSIP-C 2 (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, (b) SSIP-C 2 (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI, (c) CIP-II-C 1 (G3)1:LiTFSI, and (d) AGG-IIb-C 1 (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI.
elements.clean_text: 2  TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination in the newly reported LiTFSI solvates: (a) SSIP-C 2 (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, (b) SSIP-C 2 (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI, (c) CIP-II-C 1 (G3)1:LiTFSI, and (d) AGG-IIb-C 1 (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI.

elements.content: All of the known SSIP crystalline solvates with LiTFSI have TFSI– anions with the C 2 conformation (Figures and ). This conformation is more stable than the C 1 anion conformation by 2.2 kJ mol–1 from ab initio calculations, so the C 2 conformation is likely to be more favorable in crystalline phases in which the anion remains uncoordinated. For other solvates, however, in which the anion is coordinated to one or more Li+ cations, the TFSI– anion, in some cases, instead adopts the C 1 conformation (i.e., CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI and (G3)1:LiTFSI; and AGG-IIb-C 1 (AN)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI). The C 1 anion conformation optimizes the coordination and packing interactions between the ions and solvent for these solvates, thus reducing the overall solvate free energy, making this anion conformation more favorable.
elements.clean_text: All of the known SSIP crystalline solvates with LiTFSI have TFSI- anions with the C 2 conformation (Figures  and ). This conformation is more stable than the C 1 anion conformation by 2.2 kJ mol-1 from ab initio calculations, so the C 2 conformation is likely to be more favorable in crystalline phases in which the anion remains uncoordinated. For other solvates, however, in which the anion is coordinated to one or more Li+ cations, the TFSI- anion, in some cases, instead adopts the C 1 conformation (i.e., CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI and (G3)1:LiTFSI; and AGG-IIb-C 1 (AN)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI). The C 1 anion conformation optimizes the coordination and packing interactions between the ions and solvent for these solvates, thus reducing the overall solvate free energy, making this anion conformation more favorable.

elements.content: Two crystal structures of CIP solvates are known: CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI and (G3)1:LiTFSI (Figures and ). The Li+ cations are coordinated by two oxygen atoms from a single TFSI– anion and either three nitrogen or four oxygen atoms from a single PMDETA or G3 solvent molecule. The monomeric CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI solvate differs markedly from the AGG-I (PMDETA)1:LiPF6 crystalline solvate ( Figure S10) which instead consists of Li+ cations coordinated by three nitrogen atoms (from a single PMDETA molecule) and two fluorine atoms (one each from two PF6 – anions). The PF6 – anions are coordinated to two Li+ cations resulting in aggregate dimers. The monomeric CIP-II-C 1 (G3)1:LiTFSI solvate also differs from the CIP structure of other known CIP-I (G3)1:LiX crystalline solvates with AsF6 –, ClO4 –, BF4 –, and CF3SO3 – anions ( Figures S11 and S12) which form polymeric solvate chains in which the Li+ cations are coordinated by two ether oxygens each (four oxygens in total) from two G3 molecules and a single anion donor atomwith each G3 molecule coordinated to two Li+ cations. Notably, a CIP-I-C 2 (G3)1:LiBETI solvate with N­(SO2 C 2F5)2 – anions does resemble the CIP-II-C 1 (G3)1:LiTFSI solvate (i.e., the Li+ cations are coordinated by four ether oxygens from a single G3 molecule; Figure S12), but for this LiBETI solvate, only one of the anion oxygen atoms is coordinated to the Li+ cations. These variations in solvate structure appear to be linked to the size/bulk of the anions (and thus the steric packing of the anions and solvent molecules around the small Li+ cations), as well as the ability of the solvates to pack together efficiently in the long-range ordered crystalline lattices.
elements.clean_text: Two crystal structures of CIP solvates are known: CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI and (G3)1:LiTFSI (Figures  and ). The Li+ cations are coordinated by two oxygen atoms from a single TFSI- anion and either three nitrogen or four oxygen atoms from a single PMDETA or G3 solvent molecule. The monomeric CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI solvate differs markedly from the AGG-I (PMDETA)1:LiPF6 crystalline solvate ( Figure S10) which instead consists of Li+ cations coordinated by three nitrogen atoms (from a single PMDETA molecule) and two fluorine atoms (one each from two PF6 - anions). The PF6 - anions are coordinated to two Li+ cations resulting in aggregate dimers. The monomeric CIP-II-C 1 (G3)1:LiTFSI solvate also differs from the CIP structure of other known CIP-I (G3)1:LiX crystalline solvates with AsF6 -, ClO4 -, BF4 -, and CF3SO3 - anions ( Figures S11 and S12) which form polymeric solvate chains in which the Li+ cations are coordinated by two ether oxygens each (four oxygens in total) from two G3 molecules and a single anion donor atomwith each G3 molecule coordinated to two Li+ cations. Notably, a CIP-I-C 2 (G3)1:LiBETI solvate with N(SO2 C 2F5)2 - anions does resemble the CIP-II-C 1 (G3)1:LiTFSI solvate (i.e., the Li+ cations are coordinated by four ether oxygens from a single G3 molecule;  Figure S12), but for this LiBETI solvate, only one of the anion oxygen atoms is coordinated to the Li+ cations. These variations in solvate structure appear to be linked to the size/bulk of the anions (and thus the steric packing of the anions and solvent molecules around the small Li+ cations), as well as the ability of the solvates to pack together efficiently in the long-range ordered crystalline lattices.

elements.content: There are three different AGG-I solvate structures known: (EC)3:LiTFSI, (G1)1:LiTFSI, and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI (Figure ). In the (EC)3:LiTFSI solvate, two oxygen atoms from the TFSI– anion coordinate two different Li+ cations (i.e., AGG-Ia-C 2 coordination, Chart ). In the (G1)1:LiTFSI and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI solvates, however, three oxygen atoms from one TFSI– anion coordinate two different Li+ cations, including the bidentate coordination of one of the Li+ cations by two of the anion’s oxygen atoms (i.e., AGG-Ib-C 2 coordination, Chart ).
elements.clean_text: There are three different AGG-I solvate structures known: (EC)3:LiTFSI, (G1)1:LiTFSI, and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI (Figure ). In the (EC)3:LiTFSI solvate, two oxygen atoms from the TFSI- anion coordinate two different Li+ cations (i.e., AGG-Ia-C 2 coordination, Chart ). In the (G1)1:LiTFSI and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI solvates, however, three oxygen atoms from one TFSI- anion coordinate two different Li+ cations, including the bidentate coordination of one of the Li+ cations by two of the anion's oxygen atoms (i.e., AGG-Ib-C 2 coordination, Chart ).

elements.content: For the AGG-II solvates, there are no known examples of AGG-IIa coordination (i.e., the anion coordinated to three Li+ cations with three oxygen atoms). In all three AGG-II solvates studied(AN)1:LiTFSI, (EC)1:LiTFSI, and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI (Figures and ), four oxygen atoms from one TFSI– anion coordinate three different Li+ cations, including one with bidentate coordination (i.e., AGG-IIb coordination). There are differences, however, in the conformations of the anions. The (EC)1:LiTFSI solvate has anions with the C 2 conformation (i.e., AGG-IIb- C 2, Chart ), whereas the (AN)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI solvates have anions with the C 1 conformation (i.e., AGG-IIb-C 1, Chart ).
elements.clean_text: For the AGG-II solvates, there are no known examples of AGG-IIa coordination (i.e., the anion coordinated to three Li+ cations with three oxygen atoms). In all three AGG-II solvates studied(AN)1:LiTFSI, (EC)1:LiTFSI, and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI (Figures  and ), four oxygen atoms from one TFSI- anion coordinate three different Li+ cations, including one with bidentate coordination (i.e., AGG-IIb coordination). There are differences, however, in the conformations of the anions. The (EC)1:LiTFSI solvate has anions with the C 2 conformation (i.e., AGG-IIb- C  2, Chart ), whereas the (AN)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI solvates have anions with the C 1 conformation (i.e., AGG-IIb-C 1, Chart ).

elements.content: The highest intensity TFSI– anion Raman band near 740 cm–1 (Figure ) is due to the expansion and contraction of the entire anion. This band is the most sensitive (i.e., band position shift) to ionic association and many studies have examined this band to identify variations in TFSI–···Li+ cation coordination. Figure shows representative data for the crystalline solvate analysis. The additional bands present in the spectra are attributed to the solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Raman Spectroscopic Analysis of Crystalline Solvates

The highest intensity TFSI- anion Raman band near 740 cm-1 (Figure ) is due to the expansion and contraction of the entire anion. This band is the most sensitive (i.e., band position shift) to ionic association and many studies have examined this band to identify variations in TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination. Figure  shows representative data for the crystalline solvate analysis. The additional bands present in the spectra are attributed to the solvent molecules.

elements.content: Raman spectrum of LiTFSI (at 20 °C).
elements.clean_text: 3  Raman spectrum of LiTFSI (at 20 °C).

elements.content: Raman spectra vs temperature (°C; shown on the left) of the TFSI– anion vibrational bands for the crystalline solvates: (a) SSIP-C 2 (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, (b) SSIP-C 2 (G2)2:LiTFSI, (c) CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI, (d) AGG-Ia-C 2 (EC)3:LiTFSI, (e) AGG-Ib-C 2 (G1)1:LiTFSI, (f) AGG-IIb-C 1 (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI, (g) AGG-IIb-C 2 (EC)1:LiTFSI, and (h) AGG-III-C 2 pure LiTFSI (the dark lines indicate that a phase transition has occurredi.e., melting). Note that the additional Raman bands in the spectra for a, c, d, f, and g are due to solvent vibrational bands.
elements.clean_text: 4  Raman spectra vs temperature (°C; shown on the left) of the TFSI- anion vibrational bands for the crystalline solvates: (a) SSIP-C 2 (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, (b) SSIP-C 2 (G2)2:LiTFSI, (c) CIP-II-C 1 (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI, (d) AGG-Ia-C 2 (EC)3:LiTFSI, (e) AGG-Ib-C 2 (G1)1:LiTFSI, (f) AGG-IIb-C 1 (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI, (g) AGG-IIb-C 2 (EC)1:LiTFSI, and (h) AGG-III-C 2 pure LiTFSI (the dark lines indicate that a phase transition has occurredi.e., melting). Note that the additional Raman bands in the spectra for a, c, d, f, and g are due to solvent vibrational bands.

elements.content: In addition to this anion band near 740 cm–1, another anion Raman band positioned near 1240–1255 cm–1 has also been examined in the present study ( Figures S4–S6, S8, and S9) to aid in the assignment of the band positions for the uncoordinated TFSI– anion and the anion coordinated to one or more Li+ cations. This latter band has been previously attributed to two nearly overlapping bands calculated (unscaled) to be at 1223 and 1231 cm–1 for the C 2 anion conformation and at 1216 and 1227 cm–1 for the C 1 conformation (with several other weaker bands closely positioned). The evaluation in the present work () confirms thateven for a single anion conformationthe “single” band in the 1240–1255 cm–1 region of the spectra is in actuality a compilation of two or more bands (due to S–C and C–F stretching vibrations) with some having a much stronger intensity (activity) than others which explains the asymmetric shape of the experimental bands ( Figures S4–S6, S8, and S9).
elements.clean_text: In addition to this anion band near 740 cm-1, another anion Raman band positioned near 1240-1255 cm-1 has also been examined in the present study ( Figures S4-S6, S8, and S9) to aid in the assignment of the band positions for the uncoordinated TFSI- anion and the anion coordinated to one or more Li+ cations. This latter band has been previously attributed to two nearly overlapping bands calculated (unscaled) to be at 1223 and 1231 cm-1 for the C 2 anion conformation and at 1216 and 1227 cm-1 for the C 1 conformation (with several other weaker bands closely positioned). The evaluation in the present work () confirms thateven for a single anion conformationthe "single" band in the 1240-1255 cm-1 region of the spectra is in actuality a compilation of two or more bands (due to S-C and C-F stretching vibrations) with some having a much stronger intensity (activity) than others which explains the asymmetric shape of the experimental bands ( Figures S4-S6, S8, and S9).

elements.content: Four SSIP solvates with known structures were characterized: (G2)2:LiTFSI, (12C4)2:LiTFSI, (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, and (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI (Figures and ). These solvates consist of uncoordinated TFSI– anions, all of which have the C 2 anion conformation (i.e., SSIP-C 2, Chart ). The Raman bands of these SSIP solvates are located at the same position at 739–742 cm–1, regardless of the solvent chosen for cation coordination (Figure and Figures S4 and S5). A (G1)3:LiTFSI solvate is also known to form, but the crystal structure for this is not yet known. It is expected to be a SSIP solvate with 6-fold coordination between the Li+ cation and six oxygen atoms from the three G1 molecules, as many such (G1)3:LiX crystalline solvates are known. A mixture with this compositioni.e., (G1)n-LiTFSI (n = 3)was prepared, and Raman spectra were obtained for the crystallized solid ( Figure S5). The TFSI– anion Raman band for this sample is located at the same position (741 cm–1 at −100 °C) as for the known SSIP crystalline solvates.
elements.clean_text: Four SSIP solvates with known structures were characterized: (G2)2:LiTFSI, (12C4)2:LiTFSI, (PHEN)3:LiTFSI, and (2,9-DMPHEN)2:LiTFSI (Figures  and ). These solvates consist of uncoordinated TFSI- anions, all of which have the C 2 anion conformation (i.e., SSIP-C 2, Chart ). The Raman bands of these SSIP solvates are located at the same position at 739-742 cm-1, regardless of the solvent chosen for cation coordination (Figure  and  Figures S4 and S5). A (G1)3:LiTFSI solvate is also known to form, but the crystal structure for this is not yet known. It is expected to be a SSIP solvate with 6-fold coordination between the Li+ cation and six oxygen atoms from the three G1 molecules, as many such (G1)3:LiX crystalline solvates are known. A mixture with this compositioni.e., (G1)n-LiTFSI (n = 3)was prepared, and Raman spectra were obtained for the crystallized solid ( Figure S5). The TFSI- anion Raman band for this sample is located at the same position (741 cm-1 at -100 °C) as for the known SSIP crystalline solvates.

elements.content: As noted earlier, the two CIP (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI and (G3)1:LiTFSI solvates (Figures and ) have two anion oxygen atoms coordinated to a single Li+ cation (CIP-II-C 1). A Raman band for these CIP solvates is present at 747 cm–1 at −100 °C for both solvates (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: As noted earlier, the two CIP (PMDETA)1:LiTFSI and (G3)1:LiTFSI solvates (Figures  and ) have two anion oxygen atoms coordinated to a single Li+ cation (CIP-II-C 1). A Raman band for these CIP solvates is present at 747 cm-1 at -100 °C for both solvates (Figure ).

elements.content: Six AGG solvates and the pure LiTFSI salt were also examined. For the AGG-I solvates, AGG-Ia-C 2 coordination (i.e., (EC)3:LiTFSI) results in a Raman band at 744–745 cm–1, while AGG-Ib-C 2 coordination (i.e., (G1)1:LiTFSI and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI) results in a band at 748–749 cm–1 (Figure ). For the AGG-II solvates, AGG-IIb-C 2 coordination (i.e., (EC)1:LiTFSI) results in a band at 752 cm–1, while AGG-IIb-C 1 coordination (i.e., (AN)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI) results in a band at 747–750 cm–1 (Figure ). The pure LiTFSI salt (AGG-III) has a Raman band positioned near ∼748 cm–1 (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Six AGG solvates and the pure LiTFSI salt were also examined. For the AGG-I solvates, AGG-Ia-C 2 coordination (i.e., (EC)3:LiTFSI) results in a Raman band at 744-745 cm-1, while AGG-Ib-C 2 coordination (i.e., (G1)1:LiTFSI and (TMEDA)1:LiTFSI) results in a band at 748-749 cm-1 (Figure ). For the AGG-II solvates, AGG-IIb-C 2 coordination (i.e., (EC)1:LiTFSI) results in a band at 752 cm-1, while AGG-IIb-C 1 coordination (i.e., (AN)1:LiTFSI and (2,6-DMPy)1/2:LiTFSI) results in a band at 747-750 cm-1 (Figure ). The pure LiTFSI salt (AGG-III) has a Raman band positioned near ~748 cm-1 (Figure ).

elements.content: Figure shows a summary of the Raman band position variation with temperature for all of the LiTFSI crystalline solvates studied, as well as the pure LiTFSI salt, with the 1240–1255 cm–1 band position data also included (see also Figures S4–S6, S8, and S9). The Raman bands for the SSIP solvates, located at 739–742 and 1240–1245 cm–1, are clearly distinguishable from other solvate bands. The Raman band positions for the CIP-II and AGG solvates, however, are closely positioned in the 745–752 cm–1 spectral region. The CIP-II band position at 1242–1245 cm–1 does differ, however, from that of the AGG solvates, but it overlaps with some of the SSIP band positions. The Raman band position trends for the TFSI– anion differ from those for the BF4 – and ClO4 – anions. For the latter salts, more aggregated solvates result in Raman bands which consistently shift to a higher wavenumber. In contrast, for the LiTFSI solvates, increasing the anion’s Li+ cation coordination does not necessarily shift the anion vibrational bands to a higher wavenumber (i.e., CIP-II-C 1 vs AGG-Ia-C 2; AGG-Ib-C 2, AGG-IIb-C 1, and AGG-IIb-C 2 vs AGG-III-C 2). The variability in the band positions for the same TFSI–···Li+ cation coordination modes is due to differences in the electon density distribution and geometry (bond lengths and angles) of the anion. A discussion of this is complicated for the TFSI– anion due to its flexibility and extensive charge delocalization, but a detailed evaluation of the band positions and anion geometry has been provided for the related work associated with BF4 –···Li+ cation coordination.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows a summary of the Raman band position variation with temperature for all of the LiTFSI crystalline solvates studied, as well as the pure LiTFSI salt, with the 1240-1255 cm-1 band position data also included (see also  Figures S4-S6, S8, and S9). The Raman bands for the SSIP solvates, located at 739-742 and 1240-1245 cm-1, are clearly distinguishable from other solvate bands. The Raman band positions for the CIP-II and AGG solvates, however, are closely positioned in the 745-752 cm-1 spectral region. The CIP-II band position at 1242-1245 cm-1 does differ, however, from that of the AGG solvates, but it overlaps with some of the SSIP band positions. The Raman band position trends for the TFSI- anion differ from those for the BF4 - and ClO4 - anions. For the latter salts, more aggregated solvates result in Raman bands which consistently shift to a higher wavenumber. In contrast, for the LiTFSI solvates, increasing the anion's Li+ cation coordination does not necessarily shift the anion vibrational bands to a higher wavenumber (i.e., CIP-II-C 1 vs AGG-Ia-C 2; AGG-Ib-C 2, AGG-IIb-C 1, and AGG-IIb-C 2 vs AGG-III-C 2). The variability in the band positions for the same TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination modes is due to differences in the electon density distribution and geometry (bond lengths and angles) of the anion. A discussion of this is complicated for the TFSI- anion due to its flexibility and extensive charge delocalization, but a detailed evaluation of the band positions and anion geometry has been provided for the related work associated with BF4 -⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation coordination.

elements.content: Summary of the TFSI– anion Raman band peak positions for the different crystalline solvates (each line corresponds to the data for a separate crystalline solvate).
elements.clean_text: 5  Summary of the TFSI- anion Raman band peak positions for the different crystalline solvates (each line corresponds to the data for a separate crystalline solvate).

elements.content: One caution should be made: quantum chemical calculations have predicted that an anion with CIP-I-C 2 coordination (i.e., an anion with a C 2 conformation coordinated to a single Li+ cation by one oxygen atom) should result in a Raman band which overlaps with the position of the band for SSIP anions (i.e., uncoordinated C 2 anions) for the 740 cm–1 band. This form of CIP-I coordination is rather commonly found in molecular dynamic (MD) simulations of (AN) n – and (EC) n –LiTFSI mixtures. Thus, the assignment of the Raman band near 739–742 cm–1 as solely due to SSIP anion coordinationas is commonly done in the scientific literaturemay overpredict/underpredict the number of anions with SSIP/CIP-I coordination, respectively. It was not possible to confirm this assignment for the CIP band in the present study, however, as no crystalline solvates are yet known with CIP-I-C 2 TFSI–···Li+ coordination.
elements.clean_text: One caution should be made: quantum chemical calculations have predicted that an anion with CIP-I-C 2 coordination (i.e., an anion with a C 2 conformation coordinated to a single Li+ cation by one oxygen atom) should result in a Raman band which overlaps with the position of the band for SSIP anions (i.e., uncoordinated C 2 anions) for the 740 cm-1 band. This form of CIP-I coordination is rather commonly found in molecular dynamic (MD) simulations of (AN) n - and (EC) n -LiTFSI mixtures. Thus, the assignment of the Raman band near 739-742 cm-1 as solely due to SSIP anion coordinationas is commonly done in the scientific literaturemay overpredict/underpredict the number of anions with SSIP/CIP-I coordination, respectively. It was not possible to confirm this assignment for the CIP band in the present study, however, as no crystalline solvates are yet known with CIP-I-C 2 TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ coordination.

elements.content: This study indicates that, in addition to the number of Li+ cations coordinated, a knowledge of the conformation of the TFSI– anion is also necessary when considering the ionic association interactions of this anion, as this may significantly affect the Raman band positions, as has been reported elsewhere. The flexibility of the TFSI– anions and possibility of having bidentate coordination to Li+ cations adds further complexity to the analysis. While these issues may hamper or foil a detailed deconvolution of the Raman spectra of solutions containing a distribution of different solvates species, thus thwarting definitive band assignments for the TFSI– anion coordination, significant insight is still obtainable regarding the TFSI–···Li+ cation ionic association interactions of electrolytes with aprotic solvents using the results noted in Figure . This information is particularly helpful when combined with other informationsuch as experimentally determined solvation numbers and MD simulationsto explore electrolyte solution structures and how this dictates the resulting electrolyte properties.
elements.clean_text: This study indicates that, in addition to the number of Li+ cations coordinated, a knowledge of the conformation of the TFSI- anion is also necessary when considering the ionic association interactions of this anion, as this may significantly affect the Raman band positions, as has been reported elsewhere. The flexibility of the TFSI- anions and possibility of having bidentate coordination to Li+ cations adds further complexity to the analysis. While these issues may hamper or foil a detailed deconvolution of the Raman spectra of solutions containing a distribution of different solvates species, thus thwarting definitive band assignments for the TFSI- anion coordination, significant insight is still obtainable regarding the TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation ionic association interactions of electrolytes with aprotic solvents using the results noted in Figure . This information is particularly helpful when combined with other informationsuch as experimentally determined solvation numbers and MD simulationsto explore electrolyte solution structures and how this dictates the resulting electrolyte properties.

elements.content: Four new LiTFSI crystalline solvate structures have been determined. A detailed characterization of these, as well as other known or speculative crystalline solvate structures, has enabled the variation for the ∼740–752 and ∼1240–1255 cm–1 anion Raman bands to be evaluated for a wide range of TFSI–···Li+ cation modes of coordination. The extensive variety of this coordinationdue to both the presence of four anion oxygen atoms and the flexibility of the anionsresults in significant difficulties associated with fully identifying the distributions of specific forms of coordination in liquid mixtures due to the wide range of TFSI–···Li+ cation interactions possible and overlap of the spectroscopic data signatures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four new LiTFSI crystalline solvate structures have been determined. A detailed characterization of these, as well as other known or speculative crystalline solvate structures, has enabled the variation for the ~740-752 and ~1240-1255 cm-1 anion Raman bands to be evaluated for a wide range of TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation modes of coordination. The extensive variety of this coordinationdue to both the presence of four anion oxygen atoms and the flexibility of the anionsresults in significant difficulties associated with fully identifying the distributions of specific forms of coordination in liquid mixtures due to the wide range of TFSI-⋅⋅⋅Li+ cation interactions possible and overlap of the spectroscopic data signatures.

elements.content: Gaussian files (in .xyz format) for the TFSI– anion to visualize the anion vibrational modes for the C 1 and C 2 conformations, figures showing Raman data for the TFSI– anion bands, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) heating traces for the solvates, spacefill diagrams, Li+ and TFSI– coordination diagrams, ion packing diagrams,and ORTEP drawings, tables listing crystal data, atomic coordinates, anisotropic displacement parameters, bond lengths and angles, and torsion angles, and text giving details for the determination of vibrational modes, solvate crystal structures, and structure solution and refinement (PDF), and crystallographic information files (CIF) for the crystalline solvate structures. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Gaussian files (in .xyz format) for the TFSI- anion to visualize the anion vibrational modes for the C 1 and C 2 conformations, figures showing Raman data for the TFSI- anion bands, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) heating traces for the solvates, spacefill diagrams, Li+ and TFSI- coordination diagrams, ion packing diagrams,and ORTEP drawings, tables listing crystal data, atomic coordinates, anisotropic displacement parameters, bond lengths and angles, and torsion angles, and text giving details for the determination of vibrational modes, solvate crystal structures, and structure solution and refinement (PDF), and crystallographic information files (CIF) for the crystalline solvate structures. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Solvate
Structures and Spectroscopic Characterization
of LiTFSI Electrolytes
